repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Energy Efficiency and Renewable
            Energy Development Policy Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Energy Efficiency and
            Renewable Energy Development Policy Loan (DPL) Project for
            Poland were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: a programmatic DPL with several
            installments will likely have enabled further progress on
            the policy agenda. While the Government appears to be
            meeting its energy efficiency and renewable energy targets,
            the pace of energy efficiency reforms has slowed down
            somewhat after the DPL was approved. As this DPL
            demonstrates, it is possible to deliver reforms even under
            circumstances where achieving political consensus is at
            times challenging; a programmatic DPL could have been
            helpful in ensuring the sustainability of the reforms and
            supporting further actions. The breadth and depth of the DPL
            objectives stretched the capacity of the Government to
            deliver. A DPL series could have helped alleviate this
            constraint. For a single, one-off DPL it will have been
            preferable if the agenda centered on only few of the most
            important policies. Furthermore, it will have been also
            helpful if some of the specific energy efficiency analytical
            work currently under way would have been carried out already
            prior to the preparation of the DPL.

Poland - Energy Efficiency and Renewable

repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Energy Efficiency and Renewable
            Energy Development Policy Loan Project : summary of discussion

abstracts.cdata!:
The Executive Directors approved the
            loan in the amount of EUR 750 million (US$ 1.11 billion
            equivalent) for the Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy
            Development Policy Loan (DPL) to the Republic of Poland on
            the payment terms and conditions set out in the
            President's Memorandum (R2011-0123). Directors
            expressed support for the DPL and its overarching objective
            of significantly reducing energy intensity while
            simultaneously increasing the share of renewable energy. The
            importance of mitigating implementation risks and designing
            a program that will assist the poor in coping with the
            negative social impacts of increased energy prices was also emphasized.

14325039.trustfund:
TF099181-Poverty Alleviation Issues
            associated with Poland's Energy Efficiency P

repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Energy Efficiency and Renewable
            Energy Development Policy Loan (DPL) Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The Government of Poland faces a
            dilemma: how can harmful emissions are decreased, while
            maintaining its focus on economic growth to converge with
            the European Union (EU)-15 and do this within a constrained
            fiscal environment. The World Bank (the Bank) worked closely
            with the Government during 2009-10 to address this conundrum
            in preparing the 2011 report entitled 'transition to a
            low emissions economy in Poland', analyzing the carbon
            abatement potential in Poland and the associated economic
            impact. The analysis identified energy efficiency and
            selected renewable energy investments as the priority near-
            to medium-term investments. Although energy efficiency
            options are low cost, market penetration has been limited.
            This DPL supports policy actions that are designed to
            address market rigidities. Poland faces a problem in
            achieving bold renewable energy targets as there is little
            hydropower or deep geothermal potential and solar power is
            expensive. Biomass applications have recently shown promise
            and are, along with wind power and biogas, expected to be
            the focus of attention in meeting Poland's 2020
            renewable energy target of 15.0 percent of final energy
            consumption from renewable energy sources. To support the
            implementation of its renewable energy policy, the
            Government has established a green certificates program that
            obliges electricity suppliers to increase the share of
            renewable energy in their portfolio. In addition, subsidies
            are available from EC funds used to help decrease renewable
            energy investment costs as part of the transition to reduce emissions.
